definitions: soft thick hair covering the body of certain animals
animal pelt used as material for clothing or decoration
coating that forms on tongue or inside vessels
examples: The cat's fur felt silky and warm to touch
Arctic foxes grow thicker fur during winter months
She wore an elegant fur coat to the opera
The vintage fur stole belonged to her grandmother
The kettle had developed fur from hard water deposits
His tongue showed white fur during the illness

definitions: unit of distance equal to one-eighth of a mile or 220 yards
examples: The horse race track measured exactly eight furlongs around
The old property deed described boundaries in furlongs and chains

definitions: leave of absence granted to military personnel or prisoners
temporary suspension of employment typically without pay during economic hardship
examples: The soldier received a two-week furlough to visit family
Prison furlough programs allow supervised community visits
Many workers were placed on furlough during the pandemic
The government furlough scheme helped businesses retain staff

definitions: enclosed structure for heating buildings through hot air circulation
industrial equipment for melting metals or producing high temperatures
extremely hot place or situation of intense heat
examples: The furnace kicked on when temperatures dropped below sixty
We need to replace the furnace filter every three months
The steel furnace operates at temperatures exceeding two thousand degrees
Workers monitored the blast furnace throughout the night shift
The desert became a furnace under the noon sun
The attic was like a furnace during summer months

definitions: furniture and fittings that make a room or building suitable for living
process of supplying or equipping with necessary items or furniture
examples: The apartment came with basic furnishings including bed and sofa
They spent months selecting furnishings for their new home
The furnishing of the office took several weeks to complete
She specialized in furnishing luxury vacation rentals

definitions: movable objects like tables, chairs, and beds that equip rooms for living
examples: They bought new furniture for their living room
The antique furniture had been in the family for generations

definitions: outbreak of public anger or excitement about something controversial
state of intense and passionate emotional agitation or enthusiasm
examples: The decision caused a furor among environmental activists
His controversial speech created a media furor lasting weeks
She worked with a furor that amazed her colleagues
The artist painted in a creative furor throughout the night

definitions: outbreak of public anger or excitement particularly in British usage
examples: The policy change caused a furore in parliament
There was quite a furore over the cancelled concert

definitions: long narrow trench made in ground by a plow
deep wrinkle or groove especially on the face from expression
any long narrow groove or channel cut into a surface
examples: The farmer plowed straight furrows across the field
Seeds were planted in neat furrows six inches apart
Deep furrows lined his forehead from years of worry
She noticed new furrows around her eyes when smiling
Rain carved furrows down the hillside over time
The carpenter cut furrows in wood for decoration

definitions: act of helping forward or advancing the progress of something important
examples: She worked tirelessly in furtherance of civil rights
The grant was given in furtherance of scientific research

definitions: wild or violent anger that is difficult to control
extreme strength or violence of weather or natural forces
spirit of punishment and vengeance in classical mythology
examples: He trembled with fury at the betrayal
Her fury was evident in every word she spoke
The storm struck with unprecedented fury
Waves crashed against rocks with tremendous fury
The Furies pursued those who committed heinous crimes
She fought like a fury to protect her children

definitions: electrical safety device that melts to prevent circuit overload
cord or device for setting off an explosive charge
element that joins or blends things together into unity
examples: The fuse blew when too many appliances ran simultaneously
Check the fuse box if the lights suddenly go out
The demolition expert carefully lit the fuse and retreated
They used a long fuse to ensure safe distance
Jazz and rock fuse perfectly in their music
The novel fuses history with compelling fiction

definitions: main body section of an aircraft holding crew, passengers, and cargo
examples: The fuselage showed stress cracks after thousands of flights
Passengers board through doors in the fuselage

definitions: process of joining two or more things into a unified whole
nuclear reaction combining light atomic nuclei to form heavier ones
music genre blending different styles particularly jazz with rock
examples: The fusion of Eastern and Western medicine offers new treatments
Cultural fusion creates exciting culinary innovations
Nuclear fusion powers the sun and other stars
Scientists work toward achieving controlled fusion for energy
Miles Davis pioneered jazz fusion in the seventies
The band plays an energetic fusion of styles

definitions: quality of being incapable of producing useful results or achieving purpose
examples: He finally recognized the futility of arguing with her
The futility of their efforts became painfully obvious

definitions: period of time following the present moment extending indefinitely forward
likelihood of success or continued existence in coming times
financial contract to buy or sell assets at predetermined price
examples: Nobody can predict the future with certainty
She worried constantly about her children's future
The company has a bright future in renewable energy
His future as team captain looked increasingly uncertain
They invested heavily in oil futures last quarter
Futures trading requires understanding of market volatility

definitions: early 20th century artistic movement emphasizing speed, technology, and modernity
concern with events and trends of the future rather than present
examples: Italian futurism celebrated machines and rejected traditional art
Futurism influenced architecture, painting, and literature profoundly
His futurism led to accurate predictions about technology
Corporate futurism helps companies prepare for market changes

definitions: artist or adherent of the futurism movement in early 20th century
person who studies and predicts future trends and developments
examples: Marinetti was the leading futurist who wrote the movement's manifesto
Futurist painters depicted motion through repeated forms
The corporate futurist advised companies on emerging technologies
Futurists predict significant changes in work patterns

definitions: quality or state of being in the future or yet to come
future event or occurrence particularly in formal or literary usage
examples: The futurity of the project remained uncertain
Questions of futurity dominated philosophical discussions
The contract addressed various futurities and contingencies
Racing futurities showcase young thoroughbred horses

definitions: device in munitions that initiates explosion under specific conditions
examples: The artillery shell's fuze was set for air burst
Modern fuzes use electronic timing mechanisms

definitions: mass of fine, light fibers or particles on a surface
informal term for police or law enforcement officers
state of being blurred, indistinct, or unclear in appearance
examples: Peach fuzz covered the fruit's delicate skin
She brushed fuzz off her new sweater
The fuzz arrived just as the party ended
Watch out for the fuzz on the highway
The old photograph had a fuzz around the edges
His memory of events was just a fuzz

definitions: informal chatter or talk, especially about trivial matters
examples: Their endless gab about celebrities grew tiresome
She has the gift of gab that charms everyone

definitions: triangular upper portion of a wall at the end of a ridged roof
examples: The house featured decorative gables on both ends
Birds nested in the gable of the old barn

definitions: fly that bites livestock, especially horses and cattle
person who persistently criticizes or provokes others with challenging questions
examples: Gadflies tormented the horses throughout the humid afternoon
The cattle swished their tails against persistent gadflies
He served as a political gadfly, questioning every decision
The journalist was a gadfly to corrupt officials

definitions: small mechanical or electronic device with a practical use but often novel
examples: The kitchen gadget slices vegetables in seconds
He loves collecting the latest electronic gadgets

definitions: pole with a hook for landing large fish
embarrassing mistake or social blunder particularly in public
house or flat in British slang usage
examples: The captain used a gaff to haul the tuna aboard
Keep the gaff ready for landing that marlin
His gaff about her age ruined the evening
The politician's gaff made headlines nationwide
Come round to my gaff for dinner tonight
They found a nice gaff near the station

definitions: cloth or device placed in mouth to prevent speaking
joke or funny story told by a comedian or entertainer
official order preventing discussion of certain information publicly
examples: The kidnapper used a gag to silence the victim
They removed the gag so he could speak
The comedian's gag about airports had everyone laughing
She prepared new gags for her standup routine
The court issued a gag order during the trial
The gag rule prevented senators from discussing slavery

definitions: valuable object given as security for fulfilling an obligation
variant spelling of gauge as a measuring instrument
glove thrown down as a challenge to combat in medieval times
examples: He offered his watch as a gage of good faith
The ring served as a gage for the loan
The pressure gage showed dangerous readings
Check the fuel gage before starting
The knight threw down his gage before his rival
Picking up the gage meant accepting the duel

definitions: state of being cheerful, lighthearted, and full of fun
examples: The gaiety of the celebration lasted until dawn
Her natural gaiety brightened every room she entered

definitions: increase in wealth, resources, or advantage achieved through effort
financial profit from business transaction or investment
increase in signal power or amplification in electronics
examples: The gain in market share exceeded expectations
Weight gain concerned her doctor
The company reported gains of twenty percent
He calculated gains from the property sale
Adjust the gain on the amplifier carefully
The antenna provides significant signal gain

definitions: backward dive where the diver moves forward while rotating backward
person or thing that gains especially in value or competition
examples: She executed a perfect gainer from the high board
The gainer requires precise timing and technique
Tech stocks were the biggest gainers today
The team emerged as gainers from the trade

definitions: particular way or manner of walking or moving on foot
examples: His unsteady gait suggested injury or intoxication
The horse maintained a smooth gait throughout the ride

definitions: informal term for a girl or woman, often friendly or familiar
examples: She's a wonderful gal with a great sense of humor
The gals are meeting for lunch downtown

definitions: special festive occasion with entertainment, often for fundraising purposes
examples: The charity gala raised millions for cancer research
She wore an elegant gown to the annual gala

definitions: simple sugar found in milk and dairy products, less sweet than glucose
examples: Galactose combines with glucose to form lactose
Some people cannot properly metabolize galactose

definitions: massive collection of stars, gas, and dust held together by gravity
impressive assemblage of brilliant or notable people or things
examples: The Milky Way galaxy contains billions of stars
Astronomers discovered a distant galaxy through the telescope
A galaxy of Hollywood stars attended the premiere
The conference featured a galaxy of scientific talent

definitions: very strong wind typically between 39 and 54 miles per hour
loud outburst of sound, especially laughter
examples: The gale bent trees and tore off roof shingles
Ships sought harbor to escape the approaching gale
Gales of laughter erupted from the comedy club
Her joke triggered a gale of giggles

definitions: bitter digestive fluid produced by the liver and stored in gallbladder
abnormal swelling on plants caused by insects, fungi, or bacteria
brazen boldness or impudent behavior showing lack of respect
examples: The gall helps digest fats in the small intestine
Bile and gall are essentially the same substance
Oak galls were historically used to make ink
The wasp larvae developed inside the plant gall
He had the gall to ask for a raise after arriving late
Her gall in demanding special treatment shocked everyone

definitions: person showing courage, especially in battle or dangerous situations
man who pays special attention to women in a chivalrous way
examples: The gallant defended the village against overwhelming odds
Many gallants fell in the historic battle
The old gallant offered his seat to every lady
He played the gallant at formal social occasions

definitions: courageous behavior, especially in battle or dangerous circumstances
polite attention or respect shown to women in social situations
examples: His gallantry in combat earned him several medals
Tales of gallantry inspired the younger soldiers
His gallantry toward the ladies seemed old-fashioned
Victorian gallantry required specific social behaviors

definitions: small organ beneath the liver that stores bile for fat digestion
examples: The gallbladder releases bile when fatty foods enter the intestine
Gallstones formed in her gallbladder requiring surgery

definitions: large multi-decked sailing ship used from 16th to 18th centuries
examples: Spanish galleons transported treasure from the New World
The galleon's multiple masts carried enormous sails

definitions: room or building for displaying works of art
upper floor or balcony in theater, church, or large hall
horizontal underground passage in a mine or military fortification
examples: The gallery features contemporary art from local artists
She opened her own gallery in the arts district
The cheapest seats were in the gallery section
Musicians performed from the church gallery
Miners worked in narrow galleries deep underground
The fortress galleries provided protected firing positions

definitions: kitchen in a ship, aircraft, or camper
ancient ship propelled mainly by oars, used for warfare or trade
tray holding composed type for printing before final arrangement
examples: The ship's galley prepared meals for two hundred passengers
Flight attendants worked efficiently in the narrow galley
Roman galleys dominated Mediterranean naval warfare
Slaves rowed the galley across the ancient sea
The printer arranged type in the galley before printing
Check the galley proof for any errors

definitions: soft silvery metallic element that melts just above room temperature
examples: Gallium melts in your hand due to body heat
Semiconductors often contain gallium compounds

definitions: unit of liquid capacity equal to four quarts or 3.785 liters
examples: The car's tank holds fifteen gallons of gasoline
Milk is often sold by the gallon in America

definitions: fastest gait of a horse with all feet leaving ground together
very fast pace of movement or development of events
examples: The horse broke into a gallop across the meadow
They heard the gallop of approaching cavalry
Inflation continued its gallop toward double digits
The project proceeded at a gallop to meet deadlines

definitions: wooden frame with crossbeam used for execution by hanging
examples: The old gallows still stands in the prison courtyard
Condemned prisoners walked slowly to the gallows

definitions: chess opening where player sacrifices material for positional advantage
calculated move or stratagem designed to gain advantage in situation
examples: The Queen's Gambit sacrifices a pawn for center control
He studied various gambits to improve his chess
Her conversational gambit put everyone at ease
The company's merger gambit surprised competitors

definitions: act of playing games of chance for money or stakes
risky action undertaken with hope of success despite uncertainty
examples: His nightly gamble at the casino became problematic
They lost their savings on a foolish gamble
Starting the business was a gamble that paid off
The coach's gamble on the rookie succeeded
